list.title: Memphis Massacre 1866
list.description: National Park Service: White mobs murdered 46 Black people over 3 days. Congressional investigation led to the 14th Amendment.

list.title: New Orleans Massacre 1866
list.description: 64 Parishes: Police and white mobs attacked a constitutional convention debating Black voting rights, killing 34-50. General Sheridan called it 'an absolute massacre.'

list.title: Colfax Massacre 1873
list.description: National Park Service: Easter Sunday massacre where 60-150 Black militia members were executed after surrendering. Supreme Court ruling in U.S. v. Cruikshank (1876) gutted federal civil rights enforcement.

list.title: Hamburg Massacre 1876
list.description: SC Encyclopedia: On America's centennial, Red Shirts militia executed Black militia members after surrender. Massacre leader Matthew Butler was elected U.S. Senator.

list.title: Tulsa Race Massacre 1921
list.description: Tulsa Historical Society: White mobs destroyed 'Black Wall Street,' killing 100-300+ and leaving 10,000 homeless. The massacre was hidden from textbooks for decades.

list.title: Thaddeus Stevens speeches
list.description: Teaching American History: Radical Republican leader's demand for Confederate land confiscation and treason trials. 'Strip a proud nobility of their bloated estates.'

list.title: Stevens epitaph
list.description: National Park Service: Stevens chose burial in a Black cemetery to 'illustrate in my death the principles which I advocated through a long life: Equality of Man before his Creator.'

list.title: Andrew Johnson quotes
list.description: American Presidency Project: Johnson's Third Annual Message defending his obstruction of Reconstruction; White House biography.

list.title: Lost Cause origins
list.description: Edward Pollard's The Lost Cause (1866) named the mythology; Southern Historical Society Papers institutionalized it; UDC placed monuments and controlled textbooks.

list.title: U.S. v. Cruikshank
list.description: Cornell Law: Supreme Court ruled the 14th Amendment only applied to state action, not private violence. Effectively legalized Klan terrorism.

list.title: Sherman's Special Field Order No. 15
list.description: National Archives: '40 acres and a mule' order that granted 400,000 acres to freed people. Reversed by Andrew Johnson, who returned land to former slaveholders.

list.title: Confederate monument timing
list.description: Southern Poverty Law Center [archive]: Most monuments erected during Jim Crow (1890s-1920s) and Civil Rights era (1950s-1960s), not memorials, but intimidation.

gallery.title: Mississippi Declaration (1861)
gallery.content: "Our position is thoroughly identified with the institution of slavery... a blow at slavery is a blow at commerce and civilization." The document lists threats to slavery as the motivation for leaving the Union.

gallery.title: Stephens Cornerstone (1861)
gallery.content: Alexander Stephens proclaimed that the Confederacy stands on "the great truth that the negro is not equal to the white man; that slavery and subordination to the superior race is his natural condition."

gallery.title: Voting Rights Act (1965)
gallery.content: Section 2 forbids any voting rule that results in discrimination on account of race or color. It empowered federal oversight that reshaped Southern politics and accelerated party realignment.

gallery.title: 1972 Presidential Map
gallery.content: Richard Nixon swept every former Confederate state while George McGovern carried Massachusetts and Washington DC. The map visualizes the completed migration of white Southern voters into the GOP coalition.
